markdown: figures for American teenagers are even higher. In 1999-2000, carbonated soft drinks and fruit drinks/ades totaled 13% of teenagers' calories.7 American consumers would most certainly benefit from having the calorie information of those beverages clearly displayed on the front label particularly when increasing research is demonstrating that soft drinks promote weight gain.8 We urge Coca-Cola to follow through on the company's global commitment to "adhering to the right policies in ... the marketplace ... and promoting nutrition education" and begin disclosing caloric content on the front labels of all Coca-Cola products sold in the U.S. <::attestation: Signature Signed Signature: legible Sincerely, Michael F. Jacobson, Ph.D. Executive Director A handwritten signature is present above the typed name and title, positioned below the word "Sincerely," on the left side of the document.::> Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/kfpj0226

chunks.markdown: figures for American teenagers are even higher. In 1999-2000, carbonated soft drinks and fruit drinks/ades totaled 13% of teenagers' calories.7 American consumers would most certainly benefit from having the calorie information of those beverages clearly displayed on the front label particularly when increasing research is demonstrating that soft drinks promote weight gain.8

We urge Coca-Cola to follow through on the company's global commitment to "adhering to the right policies in ... the marketplace ... and promoting nutrition education" and begin disclosing caloric content on the front labels of all Coca-Cola products sold in the U.S.

<::attestation: Signature Signed Signature: legible Sincerely, Michael F. Jacobson, Ph.D. Executive Director A handwritten signature is present above the typed name and title, positioned below the word "Sincerely," on the left side of the document.::>
